poem:
The Tomb of Light  

Newgrange whispers   
from the earth's old heart,   
grass a cloak upon ancient stones.  
Curved walls shine, white in green,  
the earth's breath, silent and steady.  
Inside, shadows guard the light of ages,  
waiting for the solstice sun  
to find its path,  
a beam of time crossing  
forgotten whispers of life.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "10 places to see in the winter solstice in the UK and Ireland (that aren’t Stonehenge) Newgrange, County Meath, Ireland From the outside it looks like a grass-covered UFO, its curved, chalk-white walls gleaming amid the green countryside. Yet inside is one of the most impressive prehistoric constructions in Europe. Rediscovered in 1699, but only excavated in the 1960s, Newgrange in the Boyne Valley is a Neolithic passage tomb that has been dated to about". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
